name: processing of anode slime from electrorefining of copper, anode | gold | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/23118/documentation

For the processing of anode slimes from primary copper electrorefining globally.;Background: Metals are produced as part of a complex, highly interconnected and interdependent system, with many desirable but scarce/critical metals recovered as by-products during the production of one or more ‘host’ metal(s). Copper is one of the world’s major mineral commodities and is mined from heterogeneous sulfide or oxide mineral deposits in countries worldwide. Copper sulfide deposits, such as those of the porphyry or massive sulphide type, contain numerous other valuable minerals, which are desirable to society. Copper is mined & beneficiated to produce a copper sulfide concentrate, as well as other by-product concentrates (e.g. molybdenite), which are sold to smelters. Copper sulfide concentrates are smelted to produce the intermediate product, copper anode. This is then sold to refineries, where it is electrorefined to produce copper cathode, which is sold to fabricators. The by-product of copper electrorefining is anode slime, which contains various important by-product metals (principally gold, silver, selenium & tellurium) and is sold to precious metal recovery plants for further processing to recover the valuable metals.;Modelling approach: Amounts of exchanges to the environment and from the technosphere were taken from the treatment activity, “treatment of precious metal from electronics scrap, in anode slime, precious metal extraction”, which was used here as a proxy for the treatment of anode slime from primary copper production via pyrometallurgy. The amounts of by products from the process were calculated through a global material flow analysis of primary copper production. Further information is provided in the accompanying documentation (see Turner & Hischier, 2020). Electrical energy demand was based on Chatterjee et al. (1996).;References;Chatterjee, B. (1996). Electrowinning of gold from anode slimes. Materials Chemistry and Physics, 45, 27-32.;Turner, D. A. & Hischier, R. (2020). Life cycle inventories of pyrometallurgical copper production and anode slime processing. Empa, St. Gallen, Switzerland.

Upon delivery of anode slime.

The refining of gold and silver; the packaging of copper telluride cement and crude selenium.

No allocation is applied.
category: C:Manufacturing/24:Manufacture of basic metals/242:Manufacture of basic precious and other non-ferrous metals/2420:Manufacture of basic precious and other non-ferrous metals

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Production volumes are representative of the situation in 2015 but are considered valid until the end of 2019. Data sources for the inventory model have not been updated since v2.1 (see Classen et al. 2009), but the amounts of by-products have been adjusted to represent the current situation.;References;Classen, M., Althaus, H.-J., Blaser, S., Scharnhost, W., Tuchschmid, M., Jungbluth, N., & Emmenegger, M. F. (2009). Life cycle inventories of metals. Final report, ecoinvent data v2.1, No. 10. Dübendorf, Switzerland.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Amounts of exchanges to the environment and from the technosphere based on data from a Swedish anode slime processing plant that is singular in the region and ranges worldwide among the big producer. It may be taken as approximation for the global situation. Amounts of by-products based on the typical global situation.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Based on typical current technology. Anode slime treatment by pressure leaching and top blown rotary converter. Production of Silver by Möbius Electrolysis, Gold by Wohlwill electrolysis, copper telluride cement and crude selenium to further processing.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: see Geography, Technology and general comments.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Literature review and material flow analysis.

exchanges.description: Based on a global material flow analysis and the typical gold content of anode slimes (calculated as the arithmetic mean of available literature values)
